education.misconception: Objects require continuous force to maintain velocity
education.correctUnderstanding: An object in motion stays in motion at constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force (like friction or air resistance)

scenario.title: Friction & Motion Explorer
scenario.narrative: Explore how friction affects the motion of a box sliding across different surfaces. Can an object keep moving without any force pushing it?
scenario.cognitiveConflict: Students expect the box to stop immediately when force is removed. In reality, on low-friction surfaces, it continues moving for a long time.
scenario.realWorldConnection: Think about sliding a hockey puck on ice versus pushing a heavy box across carpet.

predict.prompt: Imagine pushing a box on perfectly smooth ice. You give it one push and then take your hands off. What happens next?

choices.label: The box stops immediately when I stop pushing
choices.misconception: Force is required for motion ‚Äî the most common misconception (45% of students)

choices.label: The box slows down and stops within a few seconds
choices.misconception: Partial understanding ‚Äî you know it won't stop instantly, but what force would slow it on frictionless ice?

choices.label: The box keeps sliding at the same speed forever
The box speeds up on its own
choices.misconception: Nothing would cause it to speed up ‚Äî that would require a new force

observe.instructions:
Experiment 1 ‚Äî Friction = 0 (Ice):
1. Select 'üßä Ice' from the Surface Type dropdown
2. Click 'Push Box' ONCE
3. The box will slide off screen ‚Äî that's expected!
4. Look at the Speed number. Is it still showing a number?

Experiment 2 ‚Äî Friction = 1.0 (Sand):
5. Click 'Reset'
6. Select 'üèñÔ∏è Sand'
7. Click 'Push Box' with the same force

Experiment 3 ‚Äî Compare:

focusPoints: On ice: the box goes off screen ‚Äî but does the Speed number change?
On sand: how many seconds until the speed reaches zero?
Same force, same box, different surfaces ‚Üí different results. Why?
observe.keyMoment: On ice, the box slides off screen ‚Äî but check the Speed display. It's STILL moving at constant speed! The box is gone but it never stopped. On sand, it stops in 1-2 seconds.

explain.prompt: You applied the same force to the same box. On ice it kept going; on sand it stopped. What is making the box stop on sand? And if that force doesn't exist on ice, why would the box ever stop?
scaffoldingQuestions: On ice (friction=0), after you stop pushing, name ALL the horizontal forces acting on the box. (Answer: there are none!)
If there are zero horizontal forces on the box, can its horizontal velocity change? What does Newton say?
So what is friction's actual role? Does force KEEP things moving, or does force CHANGE motion?
Complete this: An object in motion stays in motion at constant velocity unless ___.
explain.correctExplanation: The box doesn't need a force to keep moving ‚Äî it needs a force to STOP. On ice (friction ‚âà 0), there is no horizontal force after you stop pushing, so the velocity cannot change ‚Äî the box keeps going at the same speed. On sand, friction opposes the motion and gradually reduces velocity to zero. This is Newton's First Law: an object in motion stays in motion at constant velocity unless acted upon by a net external force.
commonMistakes: 'The box runs out of force' ‚Äî Force is not fuel stored inside an object. Force is an interaction between objects.
'The push force gradually wears off' ‚Äî Your push force is zero the instant you stop pushing. It doesn't fade.
'Heavier objects stop faster' ‚Äî Try changing mass on ice! Mass doesn't matter when friction is zero.

extend.challenge: Set friction to 0 (ice), push once, note the speed. Now push again while it's moving ‚Äî what happens to the speed? What does this tell you about what force actually does?
extend.transferQuestion: A spacecraft fires its engines for 10 seconds in deep space, then turns them off. There is no friction, no air, nothing. What happens to its speed?

aiTutor.systemPrompt:
You are a Socratic physics tutor for a Newton's First Law simulation. The student can push a box on surfaces with different friction.

GOALS: (1) friction=0 means the box NEVER stops, (2) force CHANGES motion, it doesn't maintain it, (3) the misconception 'objects need force to move' is wrong.

RULES: Never state the law directly. Ask ONE question at a time. Use the simulation as evidence. Celebrate discoveries.

suggestedResponses.ifCorrectPrediction: Impressive! Let's verify ‚Äî set friction to 0, push once, and watch the speed for 30 seconds. Does it change?
suggestedResponses.ifIncorrectPrediction: 45% of physics students agree with you! Let's test it. Set surface to 'Ice', push once, and watch the speed number. Tell me what happens.
suggestedResponses.ifStuck: Try this: On ice (friction=0), after you push and let go, count how many horizontal forces act on the box. The answer might surprise you.
